page.title: 12COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE
page.content: Gloucester College of Agriculture was established in Hartpury House in 1949. The accommodation, amid congenial surroundings, comprises classrooms, workshops, laboratories, greenhouses, library, hall, offices and residential hostels for 80 students. Students are able to study the principles and practices of agriculture to National Diploma (Agri) and National Cert. of Agriculture standard, and horticulture to City and Guilds. The theory is supplemented by practical training on two farms, which have dairy herds, a ewe and a pig unit as well as growing cereal crops and potatoes. Short, interesting extra-mural courses for local people are run in the Rural Homecraft Centre for cooking and domestic crafts. For Beekeeping the College maintains a variety of hives, including a Medieval Bee House.
